description: Those looking to complete the CompTIA A+ 900 Series certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the two exams required to pass in order to receive the certification. The certification is designed for entry level IT professionals with about a year of experience. Some of the exam objectives include hardware, networking, mobile devices, operating systems, security, and troubleshooting, making it a valuable certification to have especially for one just getting in to the IT career field with no documented experience.
descriptionMD: Those looking to complete the _CompTIA A+ 900 Series_ certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the two exams required to pass in order to receive the certification. The certification is designed for entry level IT professionals with about a year of experience. Some of the exam objectives include hardware, networking, mobile devices, operating systems, security, and troubleshooting, making it a valuable certification to have especially for one just getting in to the IT career field with no documented experience. __This course has been CAQC'd and qualifies for CEU credits. [Click here](https://itpro.tv/comptia-partnership) to get an exam voucher discount.__
name: A+ 900 Series
subtitle: Vendor-neutral hardware and software technologies

episodes.description: The CompTIA A+ certification provides a solid foundation for one to start to advance their career it the world of IT and measures the competencies for an entry-level IT professional with the equivalent of at least 12 months in the lab or field. Viewers will hear an overview about the knowledge one needs to attain the A+ certification, about the two exams one will need to take and the 220-901 exam objectives that is all about the idea of hardware.
episodes.title: (220-901) Overview

episodes.description: The Basic Input Output System (BIOS) is the place where every computer begins when it first boots up, and is where it starts to check and verify that things are actually where they are in the system. Viewers will hear discussions on the different functions of BIOS, how it works, and about configuring the BIOS settings.
episodes.title: Configuring BIOS

episodes.description: Knowing the motherboard and the different types of motherboards is important for an A+ technician because it is what holds together the essential parts of a system and allows them to work. Viewers will see different kinds of motherboards, where things on a motherboard are located, and the functions behind some of the different parts.
episodes.title: Motherboard Components

episodes.description: Random Access Memory (RAM) is a dynamic work area for the processor that can be used for temporary storage. Viewers will hear about different types of RAM modules and how to properly fit them into the motherboard.
episodes.title: RAM Types

episodes.description: The more RAM that is on a system is going to correlate with the overall amount of performance speed on the system.  Viewers will hear discussions on RAM to help viewers understand the different types of RAM designed for different computer systems and hear different terms associated with RAM use like single sided and double sided memory, ECC and Parity RAM, and buffered and unbuffered RAM.
episodes.title: RAM Types Part 2

episodes.description: Expansion cards make room on a motherboard for things that weren't necessarily built into it to expand the range of capabilities for the actual system. Some added capabilities that expansion cards can bring are, extra or updated video capabilities, USB, or FireWire ports. Viewers will hear discussions on different type of expansion card option to add into a system and also see a demonstration of actually plugging in an expansion card into the motherboard.
episodes.title: Expansion Cards

episodes.description: Storage devices are ways to store digital content that come in a large variety of types and can be used in many different settings. Viewers will hear about the different storage devices including optical drives, hard drives, compact disks, and external drives and also hear about some of the functionality behind each type.
episodes.title: Storage Devices

episodes.description: As technology advances, newer developments in storage devices have made them increasingly more portable and functional. Viewers will hear about further ways to store data and hear discussions on different solid state drives, flash drives, and SD cards.
episodes.title: Storage Devices Part 2

episodes.description: A Redundant Array of Inexpensive or Independent Disks (RAID) is a bunch of drives that are taken together to make one large drive. Viewers will hear about further types of storage media including the different types of RAID and magnetic tape drives and will also hear the advantages and disadvantages to each one.
episodes.title: Storage Devices Part 3

episodes.description: As a system builder, it is key one picks out the right CPU and cooling system to fit the specifications of their combined system. Viewers will see some different cooling systems used to dissipate heat and different sockets on the motherboard as well as hear about some of the stuff one has to know about the different types of sockets, CPU processors, and cooling systems.
episodes.title: Sockets, CPUs and Cooling

episodes.description: As an A+ technician, one will need to be able to identify different cables by sight, know the basic specifications of them, and know what they actually do so one can perform the task of trying to troubleshoot, install, or just make something work. Viewers will hear about different connectors like USB, FireWire, and ATA cables and also hear explanations to help viewers understand what's going on inside the connectors and see the differences between them.
episodes.title: Connections & Connectors

episodes.description: Knowing the distinctions and specifications to different cable connectors is useful information to know as an A+ technician or when taking the A+ exam. Viewers will hear about ways to transfer video data through VGA, DVI, and HDMI cables and also transfer audio through RCA and 1/8" jack connector cables.
episodes.title: Connections & Connectors Part 2

episodes.description: Wireless connection is another type of connection that can be used to share data between devices and has replaced a lot of physical means of connection because of its convenience. Viewers will hear further about physical connector cables like BNC connectors, Coax cables, and telephone jack cables and also hear about the main types of wireless technology and the general specifications behind wireless connections like speed, distance limitations, and frequency they operate on.
episodes.title: Connections & Connectors Part 3

episodes.description: Power supplies give power to all the different components inside a device, but one will need to match the same form factor for the motherboard, case, and the power supply itself to supply the unit with the proper amount of power. Viewers will hear about key features to understand when it comes to power supplies, how much power one really needs, and learn about factors for picking the right power supply for a system.
episodes.title: Power Supplies

episodes.description: Custom PCs aren't necessarily 100% completely rebuilt by every little aspect, but are more so specially designed and built to fit a specific purpose. Viewers will hear about some of the different types of custom PCs that an A+ technician might build for someone and the need to build a system to fit the specifications of a prospective client.
episodes.title: Custom PCs

episodes.description: There are multiple types of display devices, so it is important that an A+ technician understands the differences between the different types so that they can help choose/ recommend the right one. Viewers will hear discussions on some of the features and types of basic display devices, some of the advantages and disadvantages to each type, and the importance for an A+ technician to be familiar with them.
episodes.title: Display Devices

episodes.description: A projector is another display device that can be prevalent in business type settings that A+ technicians will want to be familiar with as well. Viewers will hear discussions on projectors as an alternative display device option, the advantages and disadvantages of different types, and also hear about other important factors regarding projectors including the resolution, resolution type, and aspect ratio behind each one.
episodes.title: Display Devices Part 2

episodes.description: There are a wide variety of things one can connect to a computer, which can include input, output, and hybrid input-output devices. Viewers will hear about the different types of peripheral devices that an A+ technician may support in their line of work and common devices one is likely to encounter including keyboards, mice, scanners, SD card readers, and etc.
episodes.title: Common Peripheral Devices

episodes.description: Computing has changes over time, whereas the initial need for peripheral devices was for productivity, but now has shifted for both entertainment and productivity purposes. Viewer will hear about additional peripheral devices including external touchpads, microphones, and cameras and also the added functionality that these kinds of peripheral devices can bring to a system.
episodes.title: Common Peripheral Devices Part 2

episodes.description: Making sure that a computer can communicate with a printer is an important factor when one wants to understand how to get a computer to work and how to properly use it. Viewers will hear about different ways to connect to a printer, ways to share out access to it, how to set up different security settings, and also hear about how to get a printer to work through different means like downloading a proper driver.
episodes.title: Configuring Printing

episodes.description: Different printing technologies are heavily used in a lot of different settings, even still in a world that is shifting toward digital content. Viewers will hear about printing technologies that a field technician will likely encounter, components involved with each of the printing technologies, the processes behind them, and also hear discussions on inkjet and thermal printing.
episodes.title: Print Technologies

episodes.description: Different printing technologies are often times used for different purposes that can even carry out different processes for how they print. Viewers will hear discussions on other printing technologies like impact and virtual printing and the components and processes behind them.
episodes.title: Print Technologies Part 2

episodes.description: The LaserJet printing process is an intricate process that one will be expected to learn before taking the A+ exam. Viewers will hear about Laser printer components and the CompTIA A+ Laser Printing Process.
episodes.title: Print Technologies Part 3

episodes.description: Network cables are some of the most common cables that a technician will probably find when dealing with a network. Viewers will hear about some of the most common types of networking cables and connectors and about their usages and specifications.
episodes.title: Network Cables and Connectors

episodes.description: Network cable specifications are a highly testable topic one will see on the CompTIA A+ exam, so it is important one knows about all the different kinds and types and how they are used. Viewers will hear about the twisted pair and coaxial cabling and some things one should understand about them.
episodes.title: Network Cables and Connectors Part 2

episodes.description: IP addressing is the most fundamental protocol in networking and every device needs to have it to be able to deliver data. Viewers will hear about how computers begin their communication process, how they are identified on the network, and also hear discussions on IPv4, IPv6, and what an IP address actually is.
episodes.title: TCP/IP

episodes.description: TCP/IP content is important knowledge that is used in troubleshooting basic network connectivity. Viewers will hear about some of the other fundamental IP addressing concepts that every computer has and even how to differentiate between special IP addresses.
episodes.title: TCP/IP Part 2

episodes.description: Port numbers and different protocols are different ways that computers will communicate with each other, so that they can actually get the information that they need. Viewers will hear discussions on the uses of ports and protocols between computers and how computers keep traffic separate using ports numbers.
episodes.title: TCP/UDP Ports and Protocols

episodes.description: An A+ technician will benefit from having a foundational knowledge of different protocols because as one goes on in their networking career, they will learn more and more about protocols. Viewers will hear about ways and systems that make networking easier, what the most common networking protocols do for networking, and where one commonly sees them used.
episodes.title: TCP/UDP Ports and Protocols Part 2

episodes.description: Wireless networking is one of the most common networking technologies around and is something that technicians should know in terms of basic standards and encryption used in it. Viewers will hear about different wireless technologies, wireless standards, some of the ways one can protect themselves on a wireless network, and about the interface of a wireless access point.
episodes.title: Wireless Networking Standards

episodes.description: Being familiar with the technology and concepts behind how a computer connects to a network is valuable knowledge to know when wanting to become an effective A+ technician. Viewers will hear about some of the most common internet connection types, the pros and cons of each type, and some of the terminology associated with it.
episodes.title: Internet Connection Types

episodes.description: An A+ technician should be able to describe features and discuss why one might choose between different internet connection types. Viewers will hear about some other technologies that an A+ technician will likely encounter like fiber optic and line of sight internet access and see demonstrations on setting up a mobile wireless access point.
episodes.title: Internet Connection Types Part 2

episodes.description: Each type of network has its own specialized functions and features, so it is good for one to get familiarized with each kind. Viewers will hear about different network types distinguished by geography and the different types of technology used in the types of networks.
episodes.title: Internet Connection Types Part 3

episodes.description: There are a plethora of different networking pieces of hardware one might need to run as an A+ technician, so one should try to understand the basic working of the technology behind it. Viewers will hear about the most common networking devices, how they work, differences between them, and when one would see them in use.
episodes.title: Network Devices

episodes.description: Networking tools are important for being able to test different physical network cables, wireless signals, and etc. Viewers will hear about some of the most basic hand tools that an A+ technician should be familiar with when working with networks like crimpers, wire strippers, tone generators, cable tester, wireless analyzer tools, and more.
episodes.title: Networking Tools

episodes.description: Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) helps to fine-tune a network for the number of hosts one really needs and a subnet mask helps one to identify the network they are on by dividing the IP address network portion from the node portion. Viewers will hear comparisons and key differences between using a standard classful subnet mask and Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR).
episodes.title: Subnet Masks and CIDR

episodes.description: Most laptops have very few internal components that can be expanded like RAM and HDDs. Viewers will hear about ways that laptops can have some expandability and also demonstrate how to replace a HDD and RAM within a laptop.
episodes.title: Laptop Components

episodes.description: It may be important that one knows how to access different components on a laptop in the case that parts need to be replaced or upgraded. Viewers will continue to hear about the process of showing the disassembly of a laptop so one can understand how to access components inside and hear about devices that may need to be replaced if damaged.
episodes.title: Laptop Components Part 2

episodes.description: Once one has replaced an internal component, they can then start to reassemble it and evaluate its functioning. Viewers will continue to see demonstrations on how to disassemble and reassemble a laptop to show some of the smaller connections one should pay attention to.
episodes.title: Laptop Components Part 3

episodes.description: Those at the A+ level will have to work with desktops and laptops a lot, but even though one might be familiar with working with desktops, working with laptops will actually be more complicated because everything is much smaller. Viewers will hear about the individual components and technology found in laptop display panels and some of the complexities to working with them if trying to replace or fix them for a client.
episodes.title: Laptop Display Components

episodes.description: Special features or shortcuts on a keyboard that usually involve a combination of keys can allow one to adjust the way a laptop functions or the features one needs to quickly use. Viewers will hear about some of the most common features on laptops tied to the function key (Fn) as well as different screen features.
episodes.title: Laptop Features

episodes.description: Mobile devices have created a new marketplace of items that A+ technicians will need to have some knowledge in what they do and why people would want to use them. Viewers will hear about the features and characteristics of various other mobile devices besides laptops and about the idea of mobile computing.
episodes.title: Various Mobile Devices

episodes.description: Understanding how features and characteristic work will help one to be better able to support them and understand why people want and use them. Viewers will hear about some of the other types of mobile devices that one might encounter and have to support as an A+ technician like phablets, e-readers, and GPS devices.
episodes.title: Various Mobile Devices Part 2

episodes.description: Knowing about the hardware and vulnerabilities to the hardware of mobile devices can be beneficial especially for preserving the longevity of the device. Viewers will hear about hardware that one needs to be aware of for protecting and securing mobile devices like implementing Lo Jack technology, utilizing protective cases, and adding the functionality of a credit card reader and Bluetooth capabilities.
episodes.title: Mobile Devices

episodes.description: Mobile devices have can perform many different functions and therefore are a lot of things one needs to try and understand about them. Viewers will continue to hear about a variety of mobile device technologies including different connector types for mobile implementation, mobile accessories and also hear about troubleshooting common issues like sticking keys, batteries not charging, apps not loading, and system lock-ups.
episodes.title: Mobile Devices Part 2

episodes.description: When getting into troubleshooting, one should start off by being able to tell if a problem is from hardware or software related issues. Viewers will hear about the different ways to deal with internal component failure and the importance of using the CompTIA A+ troubleshooting theory.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Internal Hardware

episodes.description: Troubleshooting a unit when irregularities happen can be an important step to prevent damage or further damage from happening to a system. Viewers will hear about the most common symptoms A+ technicians are likely to need to troubleshoot, some of the hardware tools one is likely to use when troubleshooting power issues, and also how to test for proper output voltage to the motherboard using a piece of wire and a multimeter.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Internal Hardware Part 2

episodes.description: Anything in a computer that has a moving part like a hard drive is more than likely going to be the component that ends up dying and in need of troubleshooting diagnostics. Viewers will hear about the 3 main causes of hard drive related issues as well as hear discussions on some of the other common symptoms that one would troubleshoot as an A+ technician in the field.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Hard Drives

episodes.description: When it comes to physical things that can happen to a hard drive, it can be a result from a bad connection, a bad drive, or a bad controller. Viewers will hear more about the main causes of hard drive related issues, working with RAID arrays, and some of the common errors one may encounter when troubleshooting RAID.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Hard Drives Part 2

episodes.description: A display device can also be a key component that can also have problems that an A+ technician should know how to troubleshoot and fix. Viewers will hear about some of the most common display symptoms that one is most likely to encounter when supporting desktop computers in the field and some of the most common methods used in troubleshooting displays.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Display Issues

episodes.description: Issues where a device is not displaying what one actually expects to display like the screen being too dim or the screen flickering could be a situation where a problem needs troubleshooting in order to diagnose. Viewers will hear about some additional display symptoms that one is most likely to encounter when supporting desktop computers in the field like backlighting issues and color distortion.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Display Issues Part 2

episodes.description: There are plenty of ways in which a computer can be connected through a network, so there are also plenty of things which can go wrong in connecting to it. Viewers will hear about some of the most common command line tools used in troubleshooting networking issues.
episodes.title: Network Troubleshooting Tools

episodes.description: There are a handful of different problems that can occur when using a printer, so being familiar with some of the different issues can help prepare one to take the A+ exam. Viewers will hear about some of the common symptoms and remedies employed when troubleshooting printers, some issues such as streaks, ghosting, creased paper, and low memory errors as well as some more complex printing problems like a backed up print queue and printer installation trouble.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Printers

episodes.description: The CompTIA A+ certification provides a solid foundation for one to start to advance their career it the world of IT and measures the competencies for an entry-level IT professional with the equivalent of at least 12 months in the lab or field. Viewers will hear an overview about the knowledge one needs to attain the A+ certification, about the two exams one will need to take and the 220-902 exam objectives that that focuses in on operating systems and covers topics like Windows and other operating systems, security, software troubleshooting, and operational procedures.
episodes.title: (220-902) Overview

episodes.description: There are a lot of different features within the Microsoft operating system and it is important to understand the features to be able to differentiate between the different operating systems. Viewers will hear about 32 Bit and 64 Bit operating systems and some features of Windows including Aero, Gadgets, the User Account Control, Bitlocker and System Restore.
episodes.title: Microsoft OS Features

episodes.description: Being familiar with the features inside of the Windows operating system can be helpful when wanting to complete different tasks or solve different problems. Viewers will hear further discussions on Windows features including Compatibility Mode, XP Mode, Windows Easy Transfer, Windows Firewall and Event Viewer.
episodes.title: Microsoft OS Features Part 2

episodes.description: Understanding all the features of a system is also good for understanding how a system works and the functionality behind it. Viewers will hear further discussions on Windows features including changing the default view of Control Panel, Modern UI, Start Screen, Charms, Powershell and the Action Center as well as hear about file structures inside of Windows and the importance of upgrading Windows and other technologies.
episodes.title: Microsoft OS Features Part 3

episodes.description: Installing Windows on a PC may seem like an easy task for most people, but there are actually many more methods of going about the installation process than people assume. Viewers will hear about different boot methods used to install the Windows operating system like booting to a USB drive, CD/DVD media, Netboot/PXE boot, and even Windows-To-Go and also hear about types of installations which include unattended installs, upgrade vs. clean install, image deployments, and the refresh/restore option.
episodes.title: Installing Windows on a PC

episodes.description: As a technician, one will need to be able to understand the different methods for installing a Windows based operating system. Viewers will hear further explanations about the process of installing the Windows Operating System by hearing how to prepare a drive to receive the OS, how to partition a drive, and hear about the types and differences in the filesystems that can be utilized with the Windows OS.
episodes.title: Installing Windows on a PC Part 2

episodes.description: Finishing steps in the installation process is the final stepping stone to a proper installation of Windows. Viewers will hear about formatting disks, working with device drivers and third party drivers, setting regional and language settings, and some post installation procedures like joining Workgroups and/or Domains.
episodes.title: Installing Windows on a PC Part 3

episodes.description: The Microsoft command line tools found in the Windows operating system might be something that presents a bit of a challenge to those who are relatively new to the Windows environment like the challenge of understanding the contexts in which they run and the changes they can make to the system. Viewers will hear about commands that help with disk and folder management such as diskpart, cd, rd and md and also hear about file management commands like copy, xcopy, robocopy.
episodes.title: Microsoft Command Line Tools

episodes.description: One will need to get used to using command line prompts, not only for the exam, but also in recovery situations where one doesn't have the graphical user interface.  Viewers will be shown commands that apply and verify corporate settings like GPUpdate and GPResult and will also hear discussions on recovery commands like bootrec, chkdsk and SFC.
episodes.title: Microsoft Command Line Tools Part 2

episodes.description: There are many tools and utilities inside the Microsoft operating system that can help to manage and maintain the integrity and functionality of a Windows based system. Viewers will hear discussions on utilities that help maintain the Windows operating system environment with administrative tools like Computer Management, Device Manager and Performance Monitor as well as see demonstrations on user account creation and controlling account settings through Local Security Policy.
episodes.title: Microsoft OS Tools

episodes.description: Having knowledge of the tools and utilities in the Microsoft operating system will benefit one from a practical standpoint and also for one's goals of passing the A+ 902 level exam. Viewers will hear further discussions on utilities that help maintain the Windows operating system environment and also about tools like Print Management, Windows Memory Diagnostic and the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
episodes.title: Microsoft OS Tools Part 2

episodes.description: Understanding the different functions of the tools and utilities within the Microsoft operating system can help one better understand how to more efficiently conduct tasks in a Windows system. Viewers will hear explanations of further utilities that help maintain the Windows operating system environment like the Task Manager as well as hear about managing hard drives inside a Windows PC through Disk Management.
episodes.title: Microsoft OS Tools Part 3

episodes.description: Having an abundant supply of tools within an operating system can be very useful for the amount of features and practicality they can provide. Viewers will continue to hear discussions on utilities that help maintain the Windows operating system environment like hard drive configuration through Disk Management that may help conduct tasks such as splitting partitions, shrinking, extending partitions, and assigning drive letters. Viewers will also hear about setting up Storage Spaces as well as preserving user data when migrating to a new version of Windows through USMT and Windows Easy Transfer.
episodes.title: Microsoft OS Tools Part 4

episodes.description: Having a full view of the uses of the tools in the Microsoft OS can also allow one to more effectively maintain a system in a better timely manner. Viewers will hear continuations of discussions involving utilities that help one to maintain the Windows operating system environment, which include traditional Windows Runline commands like regedit, mmc, mstsc, defrag and services.msc and will also see how to update the Windows operating system through Windows Update.
episodes.title: Microsoft OS Tools Part 5

episodes.description: The Windows Control Panel has gone through some changes throughout the years, but still houses many of the same tools. Viewers will hear about the available utilities inside of the Windows Control Panel and also about the configuration of Internet Explorer's options as well as configuring display settings.
episodes.title: Windows Control Panel Tools

episodes.description: The default out of the box experience for a Windows browser or operating system might not be the set up one will need to use in their own environment, so one might want to be concerned with Folder Options to provide one with a more customized experience. Viewers will hear explanations about Folder Options, User Accounts and the System Control panel.
episodes.title: Windows Control Panel Tools Part 2

episodes.description: Power Options is something inside the Windows Control Panel that is very important for maintaining longevity of mobile devices and laptops. Viewers will hear further discussions on the available utilities inside of the Windows Control Panel including the Network and Sharing Center as well as driver management through the Device Manager, the built-in troubleshooters inside of the Windows Control panel and others.
episodes.title: Windows Control Panel Tools Part 3

episodes.description: A network allows a system to more efficiently and conveniently share and connect to resources. Viewers will hear about installing and configuring Windows networking on a client or desktop device and hear the differences between home groups and work groups, how to access resources across the network, joining domains and sharing out printers.
episodes.title: Windows Networking

episodes.description: Remote technologies are useful for controlling facets of other systems through a network in the context of an environment like helpdesk or remote administration. Viewers will continue to hear networking concepts and technologies in the Microsoft Windows desktop environment including remote connection solutions like Remote Desktop Connection and Remote Assistance, as well as hear about how to work with the Windows Firewall, setting alternative network protocol configurations, and network interface card (NIC) properties.
episodes.title: Windows Networking Part 2

episodes.description: It's better for one to implement proactive maintenance measures than to be reactive and implement them when a problem arises. Viewers will hear about some of the most common maintenance tools and procedures that every A+ technician should be familiar with.
episodes.title: Common Maintenance Procedures

episodes.description: Understanding how different features and operating systems work can help one to become a more rounded technician. Viewers will hear about common features found in Apple's Mac OS as well as some best practices for support and maintenance including scheduling and taking backups, system updates, disk maintenance, and antivirus solutions. Other tools like Time Machine, terminal, and screen sharing are also discussed.
episodes.title: Mac OS and Linux Features

episodes.description: Some people may be well versed on a particular operating system, but as an A+ technician, one will need to be proficient in at least a few different operating systems so that they will know what to do in different situations out in the field. Viewers will continue to hear details of some of Apple's Mac OS features and then start delving into some basic Linux commands like ls, grep, ps, and pwd. Mac OS features discussed include Spotlight Search, trackpad gestures, multi-desktops, and the Dock.
episodes.title: Mac OS and Linux Features Part 2

episodes.description: Commands within the command-line interface of different operating systems can range a bit in difference, but also run very similar commands. Viewers will see demonstrations of using some of the different Linux commands in the Terminal, which is a skill every help desk technician should be familiar with.
episodes.title: Mac OS and Linux Features Part 3

episodes.description: Virtualization is a good way one can build things like testing environments and also run multiple operating systems on a single piece of machinery. Viewers will hear some of the factors to get client-side virtualization working on our client OS and also hear the hardware requirements and some of the terminology be described.
episodes.title: Client-side Virtualization

episodes.description: To even be able to utilize virtualization, one needs to first check their system to see if virtualization is supported. Viewers will see demonstrations of implementing client-side virtualization using Oracle’s VirtualBox, how to configure VirtualBox to create a Virtual Machine, and will also hear about how to connect the virtual machine into a networked environment.
episodes.title: Client-side Virtualization Part 2

episodes.description: Supporting things like applications and network infrastructure can take a lot to maintain, which the appeal of cloud services works as an easier solution for a company to maintain those kinds of services themselves. Viewers will hear about identifying different types of cloud technologies including IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS and will also hear about the differences between private and public cloud systems and common cloud terminology be discussed.
episodes.title: Basic Cloud Concepts

episodes.description: One of the major server roles that are utilized today are web servers, which help one to connect to webpages across the internet. Viewers will hear the use and properties of Web Servers, File Servers, DHCP and DNS servers be described, as well as hear about the purpose of these servers and why they’re important for organizations and the internet.
episodes.title: Server Roles and Appliances

episodes.description: Web proxies act as a middleman between requests made on an internal network and the actual services being provided. Viewers will hear about proxy servers, mail servers, authentication servers and network security appliances such as UTM, IPS and IDS and what they do. Viewers will also continue to hear about other server types that an IT Professional may encounter.
episodes.title: Server Roles and Appliances Part 2

episodes.description: Mobile operating systems can include a pretty expansive list of different features, which A+ technicians will need to have at least some familiarity with. Viewers will see and hear discussions about the most common mobile OS features between Apple’s iOS, Android and Windows Phone.
episodes.title: Mobile OS Features

episodes.description: Features in a mobile OS can provide a lot of functionality to the user and can also provide further functionality by downloading additional applications. Viewers will hear discussions on additional features found in mobile operating systems including how to turn on the virtual assistant and emergency notifications.
episodes.title: Mobile OS Features Part 2

episodes.description: It is becoming more and more prevalent that one will have to support things like mobile devices and also some of the different methods of mobile connectivity. Viewers will hear about different methods for connecting mobile devices to networks, the internet and other devices through means like mobile hotspots, Bluetooth and tethering.
episodes.title: Mobile OS Connectivity and Email

episodes.description: Adding different mobile devices like smart phones and tablets to the list of devices an A+ technician needs to be able to support, can add a bit more challenge, but is still is needed to allow full function to the end user. Viewers will hear further discussions about other methods to connect to networks including VPNs, and also hear how to connect to email servers, public (private or personal) email as well as the business email servers.
episodes.title: Mobile OS Connectivity and Email Part 2

episodes.description: Synchronizing data across multiple devices can provide a lot of convenience for a user to access their data and also provides a consistent computing environment regardless of the Windows machine a user uses to login. Viewers will hear about synchronizing user information across multiple devices (laptops, smartphones, and desktops) by using the Microsoft Account, the types of data and settings one can synchronize across multiple devices.
episodes.title: Mobile Device Synchronization

episodes.description: An A+ technician should know how to identify types of threats and vulnerabilities and understand how they work so they can protect a user’s system. Viewers will hear discussions on common threats and vulnerabilities to a system including different types of malware like spyware, viruses, worms, trojans, rootkits and ransomware and hear how they how they infect systems.
episodes.title: Common Threats and Vulnerabilities

episodes.description: If one thinks they aren't going to be subject to a system attack, they are mistaking themselves because attacks can happen on a system regardless of whether they are a corporation or an individual. Viewers will hear about several other types of attacks that pose a threat to systems like phishing, spear phishing, spoofing, social engineering, zero day attacks, and botnets as well as hear how to identify them.
episodes.title: Common Threats and Vulnerabilities Part 2

episodes.description: When it comes to security in the A+ exam, one has to be familiar with and understand the concepts of different attacks that can happen on a system. Viewers will hear about common threats like man-in-the-middle attacks and password attacks, including brute force and dictionary attacks.
episodes.title: Common Threats and Vulnerabilities Part 3

episodes.description: Having a good grasp on different prevention techniques is important for protecting against different threats and vulnerabilities. Viewers will hear discussions on prevention methods used to protect against common threats, in particular, physical security methods like mantraps, locks, securing physical documents and biometrics.
episodes.title: Common Prevention Methods

episodes.description: When trying to implement security tactics to protect a system against threats and vulnerabilities, it's important that one implements multiple layers of defense. Viewers will continue to hear about common prevention methods used in security with physical securities like ID badges, RFID, rosters and privacy filters and also hear about digital security measures like antivirus, firewalls and multi-factor authentication.
episodes.title: Common Prevention Methods Part 2

episodes.description: Besides protecting data at the source where it actually exists, one will also need to protect it as it is being transmitted across a network. Viewers will hear about further data loss prevention methods including ACLs, protecting data in transit with VPNs, teaching user education and by using the principle of least privilege.
episodes.title: Common Prevention Methods Part 3

episodes.description: One of the core challenges that one faces as an IT admin is making sure people have the right level of access. Viewers will hear about local users, groups, NTFS permissions, how NTFS permissions are assigned, as well as how they are inherited.
episodes.title: Windows OS Security Settings

episodes.description: Utilizing settings to secure a Windows OS is another step one can take to make sure the right people are accessing the right files on a system or network. Viewers will continue to hear further about security settings, including share permissions, how they combine with NTFS permissions, and also hear about how moving and copying files affects permissions.
episodes.title: Windows OS Security Settings Part 2

episodes.description: Security setting concepts are fundamental to just about everything else one would set up for, including working in a corporate environment. Viewers will hear more about security settings, how administrator and standard user accounts differ, as well as hear about encryption options such as EFS and Bit Locker.
episodes.title: Windows OS Security Settings Part 3

episodes.description: Implementing security measures to keep a system safe in turn also helps to keep the network that it's connected to safe. Viewers will hear about some of the best practices to secure a workstation like setting different passwords like screensaver and BIOS passwords and hear how to enforce settings using the local group policy.
episodes.title: Security Best Practices

episodes.description: No device should be left at the default out of the box security level due to risks from low level security, even mobile devices. Viewers will hear about securing mobile devices through means like screen locks, remote wipes, locator applications, and updates, as well as hear discussions on using antivirus and biometric authentication for mobile devices.
episodes.title: Securing Mobile Devices

episodes.description: Smartphones are a continuing growing field and is something that needs to be secured just like PCs and laptops. Viewers will continue to hear discussions on different methods for securing mobile devices, including encryption and firewalls on mobile devices, as well as enabling multi-factor authentication and will also hear about securing mobile devices to match corporate policies to help protect sensitive company information.
episodes.title: Securing Mobile Devices Part 2

episodes.description: Properly disposing of personal or company data is a necessary precaution to take to make sure that data isn't recovered into the wrong hands. Viewers will hear about data destruction and disposal methods including physical destruction methods like shredders and degaussing and also hear best practices concerning recycling and re-purposing systems.
episodes.title: Data Destruction and Disposal

episodes.description: Out of the different environments an A+ technician will find themselves, a Small Office Home Office (SOHO) environment might be one of those places. Viewers will hear about securing a wireless network in a SOHO environment including changing the default SSID and administrator password and setting the encryption level, as well as hear about antenna and access point placement, radio power levels and Wi-Fi Protected Setup.
episodes.title: Secure SOHO Networks

episodes.description: Most Small Office Home Office (SOHO) environments tend to focus their security settings in wireless access points, making it an important piece to secure. Viewers will hear about methods to secure both wired and wireless networks in a SOHO environment by utilizing techniques like MAC filtering, using static IP addresses, firewall settings, port forwarding, and port disabling, as well as hear the importance of updating firmware and physical security.
episodes.title: Secure SOHO Networks Part 2

episodes.description: When a system isn't functioning the way it should normally work, one might need to troubleshoot the operating system. Viewers will hear about some of the various troubleshooting tools within the Mac OS like troubleshooting through the Disk Utility, Console Utility, and also hear how to boot into the Recovery Utility.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot PC Operating Systems

episodes.description: In the business world a majority of the install base is Windows, but an A+ technician will still need to know how to troubleshoot Mac and Linux devices as well. Viewers will hear about troubleshooting Mac OS X software, hardware, and even network issues, as well as see demonstrations on the use of the activity monitor, the tools available when using the recovery utility and dealing with application issues.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot PC Operating Systems Part 2

episodes.description: It can be kind of different when troubleshooting with Linux because of all the diversity in the different Linux operating systems, the lack of a consistent set of tools and even a lack of a consistent location for configuration files. Viewers will hear about the various troubleshooting tools with Linux and that the utilities for troubleshooting are a combination of command line applications and GUI based applications that can help to show hardware and software issues. Viewers will also see demonstrations of using a LiveCD to help troubleshoot when the operating system will not allow you to boot.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot PC Operating Systems Part 3

episodes.description: A Windows OS will most likely be the OS one will have to deal with in the field when it comes to troubleshooting and also will be more talked about on the A+ exam compared to other systems like Mac and Linux. Viewers will hear about troubleshooting the Windows OS and basic concepts related to hardware issues that one can use diagnostic utilities like the Microsoft memory diagnostic tool and even third party reporting tools like CPUID to help identify the hardware.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot PC Operating Systems Part 4

episodes.description: Over the years as more and more features have been introduced into Windows, there are now multiple utilities built into the operating system that can automatically start to repair certain files, but when that doesn’t work, manually troubleshooting the system might be the path to take. Viewers will hear about what can be done if the Windows computer will not even boot up and also see utilities and options for troubleshooting like the startup repair, creating a recovery partition, using safe mode and some of the other command line utilities that can help with startup issues.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot PC Operating Systems Part 5

episodes.description: There is a lot of troubleshooting that goes into computers and therefore a lot of troubleshooting tools, utilities and methods to find out how to fix an issue. Viewers will hear about performance, application and display issues that are commonly reported by end users, as well as see demonstrations on the use of task manager, program installation and display settings that an A+ professional should know and use as part of their knowledge base used in supporting Windows Operating Systems.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot PC Operating Systems Part 6

episodes.description: In today's network environment, more and more mobile devices are being brought in by users, so now technicians aren't just expected to support PCs and servers, but mobile devices as well. Viewers will hear about troubleshooting mobile devices and also about some common issues like screen brightness, wireless connectivity, screen sharing and unresponsive applications.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Mobile OS Issues

episodes.description: To be a good technician it is better not to be device centric, but to more so be familiar with as many different devices as one can. Viewers will continue to hear about troubleshooting mobile devices and also about other common issues including slow performance, battery life and overheating.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Mobile OS Issues Part 2

episodes.description: When troubleshooting it's important to know how a system actually is supposed to work when functioning properly, then when things aren't working one can start to troubleshoot to get things back to that condition. Viewers will hear discussions on troubleshooting a PC, covering various issues including pop-ups, browser redirection, and slow performance.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot PC Security Issues

episodes.description: Besides troubleshooting software, one will also need to know how to troubleshoot hardware as well. Viewers will hear about troubleshooting PC security issues as well as hear about PC reset and refresh when one is experiencing system lockups, dealing with application crashes/ hangs, the msconfig utility, how to manage what applications are launched at startup, and also how to remove potentially faulty updates.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot PC Security Issues Part 2

episodes.description: In today's day of age, security is really something one has to be vigilant about and educating users is important for preventing security issues from reoccurring. Viewers will hear discussions on troubleshooting a PC and about various issues, including rogue antivirus, spam, and invalid certificates, as well as hear best practices when dealing with malware.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot PC Security Issues Part 3

episodes.description: With the wide range of capabilities for mobile devices continually growing, it is becoming more and more important to keep the data and devices secured. Viewers will hear about several tools used to troubleshoot and secure mobile devices as well as hear discussions on anti-malware, factory reset, reinstalling applications, Wi-Fi scanners and cell scanners.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Mobile Security

episodes.description: When working in the field as a technician, one will not only be working alongside other people, but also will usually have to work with handling equipment as well, which one should take the correct safety procedures when handling. Viewers will hear discussions on using appropriate safety procedures, including electrical grounding for equipment, protecting against static electricity, personal safety techniques, and regulation compliance, as well as hear about toxic waste found in equipment and how to dispose of it.
episodes.title: Safety Procedures

episodes.description: Environmental control is another part that pairs with safety procedures because it means keeping an eye out for things that can be harmful, but is also about understanding how to control that environment as much as possible. Viewers will hear about various controls to use to limit environmental impact like MSDS documentation for handling and disposal of hazardous materials and also hear about dealing with environmental issues, like temperature, humidity, power surges, dust and debris.
episodes.title: Environmental Controls

episodes.description: Privacy, licensing, and policy issues are some of the things one will have to address an A+ technician, so one should have a fairly good concept of what each area may entail. Viewers will hear about incident response when dealing with prohibited content and activity and also hear discussions on various types of licensing dealt with in a corporate environment, what personally identifiable information may be considered as and why one should try to protect that information from being exposed.
episodes.title: Privacy, Licensing, and Policies

episodes.description: The idea of communication and professionalism really come down to language and attitude to allow a situation with an end user to be handled as smoothly and efficiently as possible. Viewers will hear discussions on how to communicate properly and professionally, including the proper use of language, avoiding technical jargon and acronyms, as well as hear how good listening skills and a positive attitude are important.
episodes.title: Communication and Professionalism

episodes.description: Having the right language and attitude as an A+ technician is important because one has to not only has to represent themselves as being a professional, but also the company they work for. Viewers will hear about aspects of being a courteous professional to customers by being on time, avoiding distractions, and having respect for the privacy of their information.
episodes.title: Communication and Professionalism Part 2

episodes.description: The CompTIA A+ Troubleshooting Theory gives a systematic and logical approach to help one break down and figure out a problem. Viewers will hear about each of the steps involved in the troubleshooting theory to help one better understand the troubleshooting process and apply the knowledge when in the field.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Theory

episodes.description: Cache memory is important because it keeps the CPU performance where it needs to be so one can get better performance out of their system. Viewers will hear about the different functions of cache and why it is important for the whole system unit.
episodes.title: Additional Information

episodes.description: Alongside with having a knowledge base on different operating systems, an A+ technician will also need to have knowledge on some hardware components as well in order to pass the A+ exam. Viewers will hear about some hardware including motherboard form factors, riser cards, and power supplies.
episodes.title: Additional Information Part 2

episodes.description: SOHO technologies are a topic that's important and that one needs to understand for the A+ exam. Viewers will hear about some of the things one will have to deal with in a Small Office Home Office (SOHO) environment to share resources including some wireless and sharing protocols like Bonjour and SMB, sharing devices on a SOHO network, and multi functioning devices.
episodes.title: Additional Information Part 3

episodes.description: Some security concepts used in SOHO environments aren’t limited to only those environments, but can even be used in the context of large enterprise level businesses as well. Viewers will hear about some of the equipment one might see in a SOHO environment and about a few security centric concepts like a DMZ, private IP addresses used for internal communication, and Network Address Translation (NAT).
episodes.title: Additional Information Part 4

episodes.description: SOHO networks are smaller networks, but are still important to protect and secure as an office environment. Viewers will hear about concepts like quality of service and how it can be used to control protocols and bandwidth available to those protocols, upgrading firmware, and Universal Plug and Play technology.
episodes.title: Additional Information Part 5

episodes.description: Hardware is another topic one should be aware of as both a component of the A+ exam and for one moving into an IT position. Viewers will hear about A+ hardware including different optical disk formats, digital right management, and some Apple centric peripherals for extending functionality.
episodes.title: Additional Information Part 6
